linkTarget.anchoringText: By definition, the GOC is a bounding surface in a reservoir above which predominantly gas occurs and below which predominantly oil occurs (Ahmed, 2007). In other words, it is the depth at which oil and gas phases are in equilibrium within a continuous geological (reservoir) column. Essentially, GOC reflects gradation in oil and gas properties over depth. In theory, it is possible to estimate this transition depth by subjecting the PVT data from either the gas or oil leg of the reservoir to well-established thermodynamic analysis (Fig. 1).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Variation of C1 and C7+ compositions with depth (where Pb and Pi are the bubble-point and initial pressures, respectively)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Variation of C1 and C7+ compositions with depth (where Pb and Pi are the bubble-point and initial pressures, respectively)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 2 is a typical workflow for PVT characterisation and CGS. Fig. 3 depicts a typical output from a CGS work. By definition, the depth of intersection of the resulting gas dew-pressure and oil bubble-pressure lines is the GOC. However, to be realistic, the estimated GOC should fall within known vertical limits of hydrocarbon accumulation in a continuous reservoir column. In most cases, these structural limits are defined by the reservoir crest (updip) and either a hydrocarbon-water contact or structural spill point (downdip).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Workflow for PVT characterisation and compositional-grading simulations

formatted-caption.caption-text: Workflow for PVT characterisation and compositional-grading simulations

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 2 is a typical workflow for PVT characterisation and CGS. Fig. 3 depicts a typical output from a CGS work. By definition, the depth of intersection of the resulting gas dew-pressure and oil bubble-pressure lines is the GOC. However, to be realistic, the estimated GOC should fall within known vertical limits of hydrocarbon accumulation in a continuous reservoir column. In most cases, these structural limits are defined by the reservoir crest (updip) and either a hydrocarbon-water contact or structural spill point (downdip).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Determination of GOC from CGS

formatted-caption.caption-text: Determination of GOC from CGS

linkTarget.anchoringText: In this paper, two classes of Niger-Delta case studies are examined. These are (i) saturated reservoirs that have their GOC established by well penetrations, and (ii) undersaturated reservoirs proven by well penetrations. For simplicity, we present three examples of each class of case studies, highlighting the robustness and practicality of the CGS technique. A total of six reservoirs are discussed, comprising reservoirs A-C for class-I, and D-F for class-II (Figs. 4 and 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Cross Section showing reservoirs A, B and E

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cross Section showing reservoirs A, B and E

linkTarget.anchoringText: In this paper, two classes of Niger-Delta case studies are examined. These are (i) saturated reservoirs that have their GOC established by well penetrations, and (ii) undersaturated reservoirs proven by well penetrations. For simplicity, we present three examples of each class of case studies, highlighting the robustness and practicality of the CGS technique. A total of six reservoirs are discussed, comprising reservoirs A-C for class-I, and D-F for class-II (Figs. 4 and 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Cross-section showing reservoirs C and Fig

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cross-section showing reservoirs C and Fig

linkTarget.anchoringText: Some example tuned results are depicted on Fig. 6, while Fig. 7 is a summary of differences between the experimental and simulation results for the main fluid properties as applicable to the six reservoirs. For all the properties, which include saturation pressure (Psat), oil formation volume factor (Boi), API and GOR, the range of the average absolute deviation (AAD) is 4 - 10%. This range of AAD is generally considered acceptable in practice, suggesting the appropriateness of the resulting EOS models.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Some results of EOS simulation for reservoir A Relative volume vs. pressure GOR & Boi vs. pressure Oil & gas 5G vs. pressure Oil & gas viscosity vs. pressure

formatted-caption.caption-text: Some results of EOS simulation for reservoir A Relative volume vs. pressure GOR & Boi vs. pressure Oil & gas 5G vs. pressure Oil & gas viscosity vs. pressure

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figs. 8 – 15 display the depth structure maps and the CGS results for this class of reservoirs, while a comparison of the corresponding GOC's from petrophysical logs and CGS are compared in Table 1. In the three examples, the CGS results are in good agreement with the hard data from petrophysical logs.
